The ruling marks a significant early win for xAI, which has also filed other lawsuits against OpenAI and Apple alleging monopolistic behavior in the AI chatbot market. Elon Musk has publicly described the dispute as part of a larger fight to protect xAI’s technology from being misused by competitors
The company argues that the stolen material could allow OpenAI to strengthen ChatGPT with innovations developed for Grok, which xAI claims offers features superior to existing chatbot systems.

According to the filing, xAI alleges that Li copied confidential company files onto personal devices on July 25, sold roughly $7 million worth of xAI stock that same day, and resigned from the company three days later. He was scheduled to begin work at OpenAI on August 19.

record.text: Also a lot of it is myth-making for billionaires who want to look like visionaries. Like if Elon Musk can position himself as one of the top names associated with AI, people will be more likely to invest in whatever his next shit is.

Platforms enshittify so that they can tell ignorant shareholders they're doing something. So they can claim the latest buzzword. To assuage the fear of being left behind. These things are related to profit in a flailing-around sort of way, but are not profit.

These things are maybe a little bit attractive to advertisers, but is Facebook PROFITING from rewarding and promoting low-effort AI slop over showing you posts from your damn college friends? Is Twitter PROFITING from having a grok "explain this post" button on every post?

external.description:
Investing.com -- Jefferies said India’s latest round of Goods and Services Tax reforms is expected to revive consumer demand, while the insurance sector is likely to face only a manageable impact on profitability.
The GST Council has collapsed the 12% and 28% slabs, leaving just three rates, 5%, 18% and 40%.
The new rates take effect on September 22, coinciding with the festive season. Jefferies described the move as a “pre-festive bonanza,” adding that the timing “will benefit both the consumers (lower product prices) and the companies (higher volumes).”
Among staples, toothpaste, soaps, shampoos, biscuits, chocolates and instant noodles, earlier taxed at 18% or 12%, will now attract 5% GST.
The changes are expected to lift sales for consumer goods makers including Colgate, Britannia, Nestlé, Hindustan Unilever, Dabur, Marico and Patanjali.
Beverages such as packaged water and juices also move to 5%. Quick-service restaurants should gain from lower tax on inputs like cheese and chicken, while pizza bread moves to nil.
Apparel and footwear priced under 2,500 Indian rupees have been cut to 5%, benefiting chains such as Metro and Bata.
Internet delivery platforms face an 18% levy on local delivery services, a small negative that is likely to be passed on to users.
On the fiscal side, the government could see a revenue impact of about 480 billion rupees on a full-year basis, with 220-240 billion rupees hit in FY26.
3rd party Ad. Not an offer or recommendation by Investing.com. See disclosure here or remove ads.
However, it projected no drag on FY27 because the conversion of GST cess into GST should offset the shortfall.
The brokerage also said the cuts would ease consumer prices, lowering headline inflation by roughly 25 basis points.
“These GST cuts should help CPI inflation by c.25bps, increasing the probability of a 25bps rate cut in the upcoming meeting,” Jefferies noted.
Unlike previous tax changes, the government has chosen not to include an anti-profiteering clause.
Officials indicated that Indian companies are competitive enough to pass the benefits to consumers without regulatory compulsion.
For insurers, GST exemption on life and health premiums marks a major shift from the earlier 18% rate.
Reinsurance will also be exempt, but commissions remain taxed at 18%, creating what Jefferies called a “slightly inverted GST regime.”
The brokerage warned that insurers cannot reprice existing contracts, which could weigh on back-books.
On new business, companies may need to raise prices by 2-4% or accept slightly lower returns.
Even so, Jefferies said the sector impact is limited, “lower GST can lift sales of protection & riders-both are high-margin segments. So, we see manageable impact on sector.”

Investing.com -- Lloyds Banking Group (LON:LLOY) plans to put approximately 3,000 employees at risk of dismissal as part of a performance management overhaul, according to a Financial Times report published Thursday.
The British lender is targeting workers identified as being among the bottom 5% of performers across its 63,000-strong workforce.
These employees will reportedly be informed that they must improve their performance or face termination.
The new approach was discussed during a recent meeting of the bank’s group executive committee, the report said, citing unnamed sources familiar with the matter.
This performance management initiative comes as CEO Charlie Nunn enters the final phase of his strategic plans aimed at reducing costs and diversifying income sources at the UK banking giant.
The move represents a significant shift in how Lloyds manages employee performance across its operations.

The discussions between the global steel giant and the South African government entity have stalled as the parties failed to reach consensus on the financial terms of the potential transaction, according to people familiar with the matter cited in the report.
The development marks a setback in ArcelorMittal’s efforts to divest its South African operations.
Neither company has publicly commented on the specific valuation gap that has caused the negotiations to stall.

My concern here is for the artists who are worried about being accused having to try to prove to some group of idiots on the internet that they aren't using AI.

If you aren't using it. You're fine. You don't owe anyone a stream. a timelapse. Anything. Go make art. Relax.

THAT is not a statement based in bad faith. That's basic fact at this point. 

When I say that creatives don't owe people their time or consideration I mean exactly that.  

And unless I'm given some particularly damning evidence, I'm gonna have faith that you aren't using AI in your work.

Read:

external.description:
In an earlier blog post I detailed how to create basic home security system using Raspberry Pi Zero 2.

 

In this blog post, I show how to create an AI home security system using .NET, Python, Semantic Kernel a Telegram Bot, Raspberry Pi 4 and Open AI.

 

This is part 1 of a 2-part series.

 

In part 1, we learn about:

 	Required hardware and software
 	Main requirements
 	Installing and testing the camera module
 	Installing and testing the PIR sensor
 	Creating Python code to detect movement
 	Creating Python code to capture an image
 	Creating Python code sends a notification and image to a telegram bot

 

It’s a lot to cover so has been split into 2 parts.  Let’s dive in.
~

Requirements
The main requirements for the solution are:

 	Detect motion
 	Capture photo
 	Create message with photo attached
 	Send message to defined Telegram bot
 	Detect who is in the photo, if the person is me, then do not invoke the Telegram bot with a message and image

&nb
external.title: Building an AI Home Security System Using .NET, Python Semantic Kernel, Telegram, and Raspberry Pi 4 – Part 1

external.description:
I was recently invited on a podcast with Grey Matter to share my experience, and thoughts from a development perspective.

We discussed many topics.  Naturally AI was mentioned.

Topics we discussed included:

 	What drew me to a career in development?
 	Which languages and tools  do I use now and why?
 	How has development changed over the years since I started in the industry?
 	What are the latest developer trends I’m seeing?
 	How to stay up to date with the latest trends?
 	Why and how has AI suddenly become such a big thing?
 	How will AI affect developers and what they do?
 	What challenges are developers facing now?
 	What challenges could developers face in the future?

 

We also talk about Semantic Kernel and open-source.

 

Catch the episode here:

screenshot of document: The harm caused by these companies is extensive, but I digress on this point to focus on Adam and Sewell. Like Sewell, Adam sought companionship and needed real human help with this mental health.

Proposed “guardrails” are not enough to dissolve the personification of LLM’s

“So if ChatGPT is nothing more than souped-up autocomplete, why are so many people convinced that it’s actually ‘understanding’ and “reasoning’?”
– Bender & Hanna, AI Con

According to OpenAI’s response to the lawsuit, there are safeguards built into the program to direct people to resources, however, the longer the interactions the more the model safety trainings “degrade” and become “less reliable”. This has only been publicly revealed as of August 26, 2025. The company stated that they will be adding in parental controls soon to help protect teens, years too late. Character.AI, also announced that they have implemented fixes including a pop up to the national suicide prevention hotline and refined their model outputs.  These changes were only implemented six months ago, that is February 2025. According to the Complaint document filed as part of the lawsuit against Character.AI and its developers, Google refused to work with the developers of Character.AI stating that “C.AI technology was too dangerous to launch or even integrate with existing Google products”.

How Hackers Turned AI Into Their New Henchman • Graham Cluley

Your AI reads the small print, and that’s an issue. This week in episode 433 of “Smashing Safety” we dig into LegalPwn – malicious directions tucked into code feedback and disclaimers that sweet-talks AI into rubber-stamping harmful…

external.description: Your AI reads the small print, and that’s an issue. This week in episode 433 of “Smashing Safety” we dig into LegalPwn – malicious directions tucked into code feedback and disclaimers that sweet-talks AI into rubber-stamping harmful payloads (and even pretending they’re a innocent calculator). In the meantime, new analysis from Anthropic reveals that hackers have already used AI gents to interrupt into networks, steal passwords, sift via stolen information, and even write customized ransom notes. In different phrases, one hacker with an AI helper can work like a complete crew of cybercriminals.
external.title: How Hackers Turned AI Into Their New Henchman • Graham Cluley

external.description: You must pay for the Copilot add-on ($30 per user per month) if you want AI features in the office suite apps or chatbot capabilities that take your work into context. Some of Microsoft's 365 Business plans add this cost right into the subscription rate. You also need to consider paying extra for Teams Premium ($10 per user per month, billed annually), which unlocks additional AI features in that app, and Teams Phone (starting at $10 per user per month, billed annually without a calling plan), which adds support for cell and landline calls outside of your organization. Another available add-on, Microsoft Defender for Business ($3 per user per month, billed annually), promises AI-powered device protection.
external.title: Microsoft 365 Business Review: The Premier Corporate Office Suite

record.text: Don't confuse the terms Copilot and Copilot+.

external.description: Don't confuse the terms Copilot and Copilot+. Copilot (with no plus sign) is a generative AI tool you can use via desktop and mobile (Android, iOS, macOS, and Windows) apps, Office apps, and a web browser (including in Edge's sidebar). Copilot+, meanwhile, is a branding designation for the aforementioned class of Windows PCs with NPUs and exclusive local AI features.

value.text:
An element of fascism is a kind of upside down where the meanest, most rapacious, and least virtuous of society are loosed to bully and abuse people who genuinely uphold civic ideals of service and sacrifice.

Public service isn’t what the system is about. It’s about conditioning the national body.

images.alt:
In a FaceTime video call from the other firefighter to The Seattle Times, firefighters in their gear were seen sitting on logs in front of federal officers. Some firefighters were dismissed back to their vehicles.
One firefighter attempted to walk over to his company vehicle to get something to drink and appeared to have been called back by federal officers.
In images shared by firefighters from the scene, a U.S. Customs and Border Protection vehicle is parked nearby. Officers wearing
"Police" vests are seen arresting a firefighter, while another appears to be restrained.
According to one of the firefighters, they were denied the chance to say goodbye to the detained crew members.
"I asked them if his (family) can say goodbye to him because they're family, and they're just ripping them away," the firefighter told the Times. "And this is what he said: 'You need to get the (expletive) out of here. I'm gonna make you leave.'"

images.alt: An absurdly, comically long GPU. The PCB says "voodoo 5 9000" and it is so long that it hangs like nearly a meter off the computer motherboard it is plugged into. There are 8 rows of four fans , indicating 32 processors as well as supporting ram chips and elaborate power circuitry. There are four old school power supply connectors plugged into the back. The whole thing looks ridiculous

images.alt:
Please summarize the key figures connected to Donald Trump and Russia since the 1980s
Certainly, Shannon. Donald Trump's connections to Russia span decades and involve a mix of business interests, political interactions, and controversial figures. Here's a breakdown of the most notable individuals and moments from the
1980s onward:

I 1980s-1990s: Early Business and
Soviet Interest
• Donald Trump: Visited Moscow in 1987 to explore hotel opportunities. This trip was reportedly facilitated by Soviet officials, possibly with KGB involvement 1.
• Mikhail Gorbachev: Trump invited the Soviet leader to Trump Tower in 1988, though the meeting never happened 2.
• KGB (Soviet Intelligence): According to some reports, the KGB showed interest in Trump as early as the mid-1980s, viewing him as a potential asset 1.

2000s-2010s: Political Rise and
Controversy
• Michael Flynn: Trump's former National Security Advisor. Resigned after misleading officials about conversations with the
Russian ambassador regarding sanctions 3.
• Paul Manafort: Trump's 2016 campaign chairman. Had prior business dealings with pro-Russian interests in Ukraine.
• Carter Page: Foreign policy advisor to Trump's campaign. His contacts with Russian officials drew FBI scrutiny.
• George Papadopoulos: Campaign advisor who communicated with individuals tied to Russian interests and later pleaded guilty to lying to the FBI.
• Roger Stone: Longtime Trump ally.
Investigated for connections to WikiLeaks and Russian-hacked Democratic emails.
• Russian Ambassador Sergey Kislyak: Met with several Trump campaign officials, including Flynn and Sessions.

Other Notables and Allegations
• Christopher Steele: Former British intelligence officer who compiled the controversial Steele dossier alleging Russian kompromat on Trump.
• Felix Sater: Russian-American businessman and former Trump associate involved in efforts to build Trump Tower Moscow.
• Vladimir Putin: Russian President. Trump expressed admiration for Putin and was criticized for perceived closeness during his presidency.
Would you like a visual timeline or a deeper dive into any of these figures or events? I can also explore how these relationships evolved post-2016.
